subject: Re: [junit] Testing singleton patterns
msgSnippet: Cédric, ... I wouldn t. Testing blah() via the TestFoo implementation should suffice. The only thing that s not tested is whether TheOneTrueFoo.getInstance()
messageBody:
Cédric,

> On 7/30/07, jason r tibbetts <tibbettj@...
> <mailto:tibbettj%40verdi.iisd.sra.com>> wrote:
>
> > I don't see any mention yet in this thread of the simplest solution of
> > them all: put all of the singleton's implementation in a non-singleton
> > abstract base class, then subclass it as a singleton. The abstract base
> > class can be subclassed separately for testing. In other words,
> >
> > // abstract base class
> > public abstract class Foo {
> > protected Foo() { }
> >
> > public String getBar() { return "bar!"; }
> > }
> >
> > // singleton implementation
> > public final class TheOneTrueFoo extends Foo {
> > private TheOneTrueFoo() { super(); }
> >
> > public static Foo getInstance() { return foo; }
> >
> > private final static Foo = new TheOneTrueFoo();
> > }
>
> I don't see how this helps... How would you test the following code:
>
> public void hardToTest() {
> TheOneTrueFoo.getInstance().blah();
> }

I wouldn't. Testing blah() via the TestFoo implementation should
suffice. The only thing that's not tested is whether
TheOneTrueFoo.getInstance() returns a valid, non-null, etc. instance of
a Foo.

>
